questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
A client plans to implement a case resolution process.
Which field types does the Case Resolution form use? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: The answer is hole number please for Billable. Customization>Customize the system>Case Resolutions> Fields>Actualdurationminues>Type is Whole number

comments.content: Not actually it is an option set

discussion.content: i think the Field "Billable" time" should be a "Whole Number" because it has to be something countable and it might differ from case to case, so how many options should an optionsret contain??
billable time is: Whole number! Time spent on the case resolution activity.
all correct except for Billable: should be whole number (used for hours or minutes)
on exam 27.11.21
Isn't Billable time a whole number of hours consumed? I use this up to 10 times a day!
Billable time is an Option set and the options are auto updated based on the calculated Time spent so all the answers are correct.

1. Option set
 2. Text
 3. Calculated (Whole Number)
 4. Whole Number
Text
People are confusing the drop down control as an Option Set. When in this case it is a Whole Number field with a Format of "Duration". Answer should be Whole Number.
Billable time is a whole number. Verified in Customer Service Hub.

comments.content: Absolutely agree. People are confusing the drop down control as an Option Set. When in this case it is the Duration format of a Whole Number field.

discussion.content: I just open the Resolve Case dialog. I confirmed the field "Billable Time" is Option Set in form

For billable time , it's confusing. The 'field type' as per question is neither. The display format shows as an Optionset but the formal name in D365 is "Duration" for time in minutes (stored as whole number) which auto-formats into an Optionset of user friendly minutes, hours, days... which can be overwritten with manual entry.

In this article the field type is 'Simple', data type is 'Whole Number' and format is 'Duration'. https://www.arbelatech.com/insights/blog/how-to-use-duration-fields-in-dynamics-365-for-sales.html 

My personal choice is to go with Optionset.
Look at all these field descriptions on the Case Resolution Entity
Billable Time is set as "Duration", therefore, technically, a "Whole Number"
The question is "Which field types does the Case Resolution FORM use". Asking abut the form not the data. The form is using an Option Set

Resolution Type is Option Set correct
Resolution is Text correct
Total Time is Calculated correct
Billable time is Whole Number [given answer optionset is wrong]
Remarks is Text correct
is question about data type or field type?for data type -> it should be whole number. for field type, will it be option set?

Just to add evidence
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customerengagement/on-premises/customize/types-of-fields#BKMK_WholeNummberFormatOptions

Duration:
This format option can be used to display a list of duration options. But the data stored in the database is always a number of minutes. The field looks like a drop-down list and provides suggested options like 1 minute, 15 minutes, 30 minutes all the way up to 3 days. People can choose these options. However, people can also just type in a number of minutes and it resolves to that period of time. For example, type in 60 and it resolves to 1 hour. Or they can enter “1 hour” or “2 days” and it will resolve to display that time.

The duration must be entered in the following format: “x minutes”, “x hours” or “x days”. Hours and days can also be entered using decimals, for example, “x.x hours” or “x.x days”.

NOTE: Values must be expressible in minutes, sub-minute values will be rounded to the nearest minute.

Billable Time is a Whole Number because you can enter values different from the options presented. For example: The field Resolution Type is an option set, you are unable to enter values different from the options presented. But the Billable Time field you can enter values different as: 3 minutes.

comments.content: Advanced Settings > Customizations > Customize the System > Entities > Case Resolution > Fields > Timespent aka Billable Time > Data Type is whole number

discussion.content: Data Type for Billable Time on Customizations say Whole Number.
Duration fields are whole numbers displayed as optionsets for presets, however you can type in your own numbers

billable time is whole number , as after you select its type as whole number you can change field format to be duration , when you enter any value of it it will open an option set but you can enter any value , so I'll go with Whole Number answer
Answer is correct - 5/31/20 - Tested in system by resolving a case

comments.content: No it is not, in Billable time you can actually type in the number...Option Set you can only choose from the pre-set options...Billable time is a Whole Number because it is a Duration field

discussion.content: i have verified in CRM, billable field is whole number type, you can also check in Case resolution entity to confirm this.
Tested on 5/25/20 - answers are correct

comments.content: I checked the solution form and both the Total time and Billable time fields are whole number type. The total time field also should be whole number.

discussion.content: Billable time field is whole number. You see a list of options when you click; which is made for easier usage. But if you check in the customizations you can see the field type is whole number.
I agree with Emdy and SoMuchConfusion : the field Billable time is not an option set, you can enter any valid value like 2.5 hours, 11 minutes etc.
the answers are correct!

comments.content: seems like more people are saying Billable time should be a Whole Number. so this comment could not be correct.

discussion.content: Given answers are correct

Billable Time is the Label on the form, the Field name is Time Spent and that's a Whole Number field. Conclusion yours!
I Vote "Whole Number"
Answers are correct
Billable time is definitely option set

comments.content: It *looks* like an option set, but you can type in any whole number of minutes that you like. In fact, if you type in something random, like "test" and tab out of the field, you'll get a notification "Enter a number between 0 and 2,147,483,647". That is pretty clearly a Whole Number field behind the scenes!

This is completely wrong, you are only confusing others with your conclusions. The field is a Whole Number of Type "Duration" which makes it look similar to an option set but in fact it's a whole number with pre-defined values.

discussion.content:
no, it's not. There is no documentation of the case resolution form and their field but let remove the answers that are clearly wrong and you have only 1 answer left ;)

1. The field is not a "Whole Number" as when you click on the field a list of values are shown and you can not enter any custom value by yourself.

2. The field is not calculated as the user has to select a value by himself.

Leaves only "Option Set". So you only select this one.

questions.question_text:
A company implements Dynamics 365 for Customer Service. You are assigned a case.
You accidently close the case before completing your work.
You need to ensure that you can continue to work on the case.
What should you do?

comments.content: lol if you got this wrong.....then you need to leave this exam prep and start actually learning. If you're reading this, please take the time to go mess around in a sandbox account.

discussion.content: Hopefully nobody gets this one wrong on the test!
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
on exam 27.11.21

This would be giving away points for free haha. 
Answer is correct - B - Reactivate the case
B is correct

comments.content: now, the case needs to be activated again to set it to in progress

discussion.content: Should it be D?
another badly worded question. "Close" the case implies you just close the page/screen. they should say "Resolve" the Case.

comments.content: agreed lol. I thought the same thing when reading the question

choices.D: Change the status reason to In Progress

discussion.content:
Seems correct, based on https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/user-guide-customer-service#merge-similar-cases. In particular, the article states:

"When a case is merged, the state of the case is changed to canceled, and the status is changed to merged. This is because it is merged into another case and all of the open case activities, emails, and attachments are now associated with the case it was merged into." 

This seems to answer both scenarios, and agrees with the shown solution.
This question was on the exam.
Correct
Can we merge activities?

after duplicate merged ---> Merged and Cancelled
open activities --> Moved to Merged
Correct

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You are a Dynamics 365 for Customer Service administrator. You enable full-text, relevance, and category search.
You need to use the knowledge base search control to locate knowledge base articles that contain each of the following words anywhere in an article, regardless of which product an article refers to:

Elevator -
//IMG//

✑ Motor
✑ Sizing
How should you configure the search? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Answers are correct.

I encourage you to read Neil Parkhurst's blog on Relevance Search. This talks about Query Characters which is what this syntax is basically.
https://neilparkhurst.com/2018/11/02/mb2-717-certification-microsoft-dynamics-for-sales-global-search/

comments.content:
question is asking to search for each of the words, so + is the query character to use.

Will search for results that contain both works. Such as Datum+Corporation. Note, the words do not have to be together, but proximity will score higher on relevance.

discussion.content:
Search in single article use +
search in multiple article use |
Answer correct

Answers seem correct:
https://community.dynamics.com/crm/b/meganwalker/posts/query-syntax-for-relevance-search-in-customer-engagement-apps
I think the answer is "|". When I tried "+" did not work. "*" is wildcard character.

I think that for second question we don't know if Relevance search is activated or not. So using full text search you need the + to select all. For relevance search really it doesn't matter it will return results using + or * or just space.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/search-knowledge-articles-csh


Answer seems correct
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/search/query-simple-syntax relevance sure uses this syntax

comments.content:
Yes - Second answer is correct. from reference link:
"Type car+silver+2-door to find only matches that include all three words."
The requirement was to "locate knowledge base articles that contain each of the following words anywhere in an article". *each*.

I checked but it doesn't work on my trial system. When I used the space after "+" it worked. I'm confused because the answer is written without spaces.
While I was checking the Elevator * Motor * sizing options, it searched correctly

So I don't know which answer is correct

discussion.content: Can anyone confirm the second answer given (using the "+" joiner syntax) is correct? I've been trying to find info on relevance search syntax but so far coming up empty.
